etymology.description: 人(人) (rén, "person") in 宀(宀) (mián, "roof") = guest in a house + 貝(貝) (bèi, "valuables") added later for gift -> 賓 (bīn, "guest")
etymology.interpretation: The combination of a person under a roof signifies a guest, while the addition of valuables implies the offering of gifts to a host, encapsulating the full meaning of a welcomed guest.
etymology.simplification: 賓(賓) -> 宀(宀) (mián, "roof") + 兵(兵) (bīng, "soldier") as a phonetic replacement given its simplicity and similar pronunciation, officially adopted in 1956.

examples.chinese: 宴会开始前(宴會開始前)，主人已经迎接宾客(主人已經迎接賓客)。
examples.pinyin: Yànhuì kāishǐ qián, zhǔrén yǐjīng yíngjiē bīn kè.
examples.english: Before the banquet began, the host had already welcomed the guests.

examples.chinese: 宴席上的宾客热情洋溢(宴席上的賓客熱情洋溢)。
examples.pinyin: Yànxí shàng de bīn kè rèqíng yángyì.
examples.english: The guests at the banquet were full of enthusiasm.
